results.title: Control of bacteria in food
results.creator_credit: J Lyons and Gate Film Production
results.brief_description: A study of bacteria and how they can be controlled in food. Special photographic techniques are used to show the shape of bacteria and their method of multiplying. An experiment demonstrates that bacteria flourish in dirt; thus cleanliness is essential when handling food. Experiments with milk prove that heating destroys bacteria and cooling retards their growth.

results.title: Control by budgeting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of forecasting, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Shows how budgets can be prepared to avoid running a business at a loss.

group_siblings.title: Investment planning
group_siblings.creator_credit: David Hargreaves, Paul Ellis and BBC-TV

results.title: Contracting out
results.creator_credit: Bill Davies and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: What can a truck driver do if his company decides to rent trucking services and to let him go? More and more companies find it practical to “contract out” subsidiary operations such as the trucking of their goods, with consequent layoff of some men. A common cause of industrial disputes, this problem is dramatized to provide ground for discussion.

results.title: Contraception
results.creator_credit: Ben Norman, FilmFair Communications and John Wiley
results.brief_description: Points out the needs for contraceptives during intercourse. Shows the various kinds of contraceptives used today, covering the history of its development, physical properties, the contraceptive principle behind it, and using live photography to show how it works. Discusses the advantages, disadvantages and comparative effectiveness of each method.

results.title: The Continuous woman
results.brief_description: Entirely the product of collective effort, this film attempts the portrayal of real images of women by looking at five individuals who recognize their strengths and the possibility of alternative roles to those of tradition. Each woman speaks about herself and the portraits merge with one another in a continuous stream of music and photography toward a totality of impression.

results.title: Continuous observation
results.creator_credit: Margaret Thomson, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: The case-history of a woman patient who has attempted suicide is used to illustrate the techniques of continuous observation. A sequence revealing the patient’s feelings enables the audience to understand them and also to share in the thoughts of the student who is nursing her. Later, in a group analysis, the Sister makes it clear that while text-book rules form a basis on which to work, real psychiatric nursing depends on the use of imagination to gain an insight into the patient’s problems.

results.title: A Continuing responsibility
results.creator_credit: Bonnie Sherr Klein, Barrie Howells, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Produced as part of the Challenge for Change Program, this series examines Saul Alinsky’s method of organising communities into effective action units based on participation democracy. As demonstrated in the Woodland Organisation in Chicago, Alinsky’s technique creates ongoing organisations firmly rooted in the community.

results.title: Continental drift
results.creator_credit: Co Hoedeman, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An exposition through film animation of the theory that Earth’s land areas are fluid and that, in the process of a slow, rolling, boiling motion, one part of the Earth might well be engulfed and then rise again some distance away, much the same as froth on a kettle of soup. From this theory comes the idea that continents were formed from one super-continent that broke up, whose pieces sank, and then rose once more, but far apart. Introducing the film is Professor J. Tuzo Wilson, geophysicist, University of Toronto. Animation by Co Hoedeman. (Award: London.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Co Hoedeman, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Contemporary Scandinavia: common purposes, individual differences
results.creator_credit: Richard Kaplan, McGraw-Hill Films and Richard Kaplan Productions
results.brief_description: An overview of modern life in Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Describes their unique political organisation, stressing at the same time, national differences. Discusses the influence of both geography and modern technology on economic and social organisation, and Scandinavia’s role in world affairs. Includes a sequence on youth and education.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Kaplan, McGraw-Hill Films and Richard Kaplan Productions

results.title: Container port
results.creator_credit: Ian Woolfe, Edgar H. Anstey, James Ritchie, British Transport Films and IC Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the development of Tilbury into Britain’s biggest and newest container port, built and equipped to tranship standard maritime containers which are the key to a world-wide revolution in freight handling. Commentary by John Stockbridge.
